title: Whistling fence force New Zealand residents to leave home
title_page: Whistling fence force New Zealand residents to leave home | Daily Mail Online
text:
The noise from balcony railings that whistle as the wind passes through has become so loud it has forced some elderly New Zealand residents out of their home.
Neighbours of the million dollar Barrington apartments on Great North Road in Auckland say people come from blocks away to investigate the noise, the New Zealand Herald reported.
'When it gets really bad, you get to screaming point,' said Sherrol Manton, 71, who lives in a retirement village next to the apartments.

'We get on the bus, go downtown and have a break.'
The developer behind the apartment block, Craig Kells, has acknowledged the whistling noise is an issue.
He said one set of repairs had already been done, and more are planned.
'We have had the rail supplier back on site and added extra horizontal supports to try and mitigate this problem. This has helped but not fixed the issue,' Mr Kells said.
Virgil Roberts from Fresh Realty is advertising the noisy apartments and admits it has been an 'issue' trying to work out where the sound is coming from.
'Whistling railings have been in different places, where someone has put something up, just like vertical louvres, which can also whistle, depending on the distances of the blades to each other and the width of the louvres,' Roberts said.
Six units have been sold and the remaining two are on the market for $1.75 million to $1.89 million.
